thread.title: Redskins-Bucs: Game day notes and fast facts
thread.title_full: Redskins-Bucs: Game day notes and fast facts

author: Mike Jones
title: Redskins-Bucs: Game day notes and fast facts
text:
By Mike Jones October 25 at 10:31 AM Follow @mikejoneswapo Washington Redskins cornerback Bashaud Breeland will try to snag another INT against the Bucs. (AP Photo/Gary Hershorn) 
The Washington Redskins and Tampa Bay Buccaneers meet today for the 22nd time in the history of these two franchises. 
The Buccaneers own a 10-9 record against the Redskins in regular season play, and the teams split their two postseason matchups. 
Tampa Bay won the last meeting – Nov. 16, 2014 – by a score of 27-7 at FedEx Field. 
The Redskins will celebrate their annual “alumni homecoming weekend,” and will wear their throwback uniforms, which represent a look similar to the threads the team sported back in 1932. They’ll have a darker burgundy jersey, and pants that are actually gold in color. The one main difference will be the helmets, which are the normal helmets, but with the stripes down the middle removed. Back in 2012, the team wore helmets designed to look like leather, but the league has since ruled that teams can’t wear alternate helmets for safety reasons. So, these will be the burgundy helmets with the usual logo of the Native American on each side. 
At halftime, the team will induct former center Jeff Bostic, a member of the famed Hogs, into the Ring of Honor. 
In case you missed them, here are the key matchups and top five story lines of this game . Now, here are some other things to keep an eye out for today. Washington seeks its third consecutive Week 7 matchup today, and will try to snap a two-game losing streak and get its first win since beating the Eagles on Oct. 4. A win today would give the Redskins their third straight home victory, which would represent a first since a four-game win streak at FedEx Field in 2012. With a win today, Washington would beat its first NFC South opponent since Sept. 30, 2012, when they beat the Bucs. A victory today would improve the Redskins’ all-time record to 5-1 against teams coached by Lovie Smith. The Redskins face the team that held the No. 1 pick in the most recent draft for the sixth time in the last seven seasons. Washington’s defense aims to record at least three takeaways in a third consecutive game for the first time since doing so in Weeks 9-12 of the 2003 season. The Redskins aim to finish with a positive turnover margin in four straight games for the first time since Weeks 14-17 of the 2012 season. Washington’s defense will try to hold an opponent scoreless on its opening drive for the seventh straight week. Cornerback Bashaud Breeland enters this game with an interception in back-to-back games. His two interceptions tied a career high. He will try to extend his streak to three games. If so, Breeland would become the first Redskins player to record an interception in three straight weeks since London Fletcher did so in Weeks 14-16 of the 2012 season. Quarterback Kirk Cousins needs 30 pass completions today to become the first Redskins quarterback since 1960 to post three 30-completion games in a single season. He currently is tied with Sonny Jurgensen (1967), Jason Campbell (2007) and Robert Griffin III (2013) with two. Cousins has thrown a touchdown in six straight games, which represents a career-best mark. Wide receiver Pierre Garcon needs 94 receiving yards to pass Roy Jefferson (1971-76) for 12th on the franchise’s all-time receiving list. Garcon currently has 3,026 receiving yards since signing with Washington in 2012. Kicker Dustin Hopkins has a chance to become the first kicker in team history to make a 50-yard field goal in three straight games. Linebacker Ryan Kerrigan needs a sack to break his tie with Ken Harvey (1994-99) for fourth place on the team’s sacks list. They each currently have 41.5 sacks to their names. 
Some connections between these teams: Tampa Bay tight end coach Jon Embree held the same position with the Redskins in 2010. Redskins team president Bruce Allen served as general manager of the Buccaneers from 2004-08. Coach Jay Gruden served as an offensive assistant for Tampa Bay from 2002-08. Offensive coordinator Sean McVay also served as an offensive assistant with the Bucs in 2008. Redskins receivers coach Ike Hilliard played for Tampa Bay from 2005-08. Redskins director of player operations Paul Kelly held the same title with Tampa Bay from 2004-08. Redskins front office executive Doug Williams played for Tampa Bay from 1978-82. The Bucs drafted Williams 17th overall. Williams also worked in the Bucs’ front office from 2004-10. Redskins linebacker Mason Foster played for the Bucs from 2011-14. Safety Dashon Goldson played for Tampa Bay from 2013-14. Redskins defensive end Stephen Paea played under Bucs coach Lovie Smith in Chicago from 2011-13. Former Bears teammates defensive tackle Henry Melton, cornerback Tim Jennings and safety Major Wright all now play for Tampa Bay. Jennings and Garcon played together in Indianapolis from 2008-09. Redskins defensive backs coach Perry Fewell and Smith worked together in St. Louis in 2003. Smith was the Rams’ defensive coordinator that year, and Fewell coached the defensive backs. Defensive end Jason Hatcher and Melton, Bucs cornerback Mike Jenkins, linebacker Bruce Carter, cornerback Sterling Moore, linebacker Drie Lemon all played for the Cowboys at various points from 2006-14. Nose tackle Terrance Knighton and Buccaneers kicker Connor Barth played together in Denver in 2014. Defensive end Ricky Jean Francois and Bucs tackle Gosder Cherilus played together in Indianapolis in 2013 and 2014. Tight end Derek Carrier and Bucs tight end Brandon Myers played together in Oakland in 2012. Safety Jeron Johnson, tight end Anthony McCoy and Bucs defensive tackle Clinton McDonald, center Evan Smith and defensive lineman Tony McDaniel all played together in Seattle at various points from 2010-14. Cousins, safety Trenton Robinson and Bucs defensive end William Gholston played together at Michigan State from 2010-11. Linebacker Will Compton, guard Spencer Long and Bucs linebacker Lavonte David played together at Nebraska from 2010-11. Tackle Trent Williams, punter Tress Way and Bucs defensive tackle Gerald McCoy played together at Oklahoma from 2008-09. Linebacker Perry Riley Jr. and Bucs wide receiver Russell Shepard played together at LSU in 2009. Kerrigan and Bucs tackle Kevin Pamphile played together at Purdue from 2009-10. Cornerback Will Blackmon and Cherilus played at Boston College from 2004-05. Hopkins, running back Chris Thompson and Bucs quarterback Jameis Winston played together at Florida State in 2012. Defensive end Kedric Golston and Bucs cornerback Tim Jennings played together at Georgia from 2002-05. Mike Jones covers the Washington Redskins for The Washington Post. When not writing about a Redskins development of some kind – which is rare – he can be found screaming and cheering at one of his kids’ softball, baseball, soccer or basketball games. sports Success!
